title: Boris Johnson loses vote to call a general election
text:

Boris Johnson's bid for a winter election was dealt a heavy - but not fatal - blow as MPs rejected a bid to dissolve Parliament for a poll.

MPs knocked back the PMs bid under the Fixed Term Parliament Act, after Labour said the Prime Minister's word couldn't be trusted.

The motion required a two-thirds Commons majority - 434 MPs - to agree to an election on December 12.

But it was backed by just 299 MPs, the third time the Commons has rejected Mr Johnson's call.

After the result the PM announced that the government would back a so called 'one line Bill' to secure an election - which would require just a simple majority.

Accusing Mr Corbyn of "running away from the judgement of the people" the PM said the country should be given a choice.

Mr Johnson said: "We will not allow this paralysis to continue, and one way or another we must proceed straight to an election.

"So later on this evening, the Government will give notice of presentation for a short Bill for an election on December 12 so we can finally get Brexit done."

He added: "This House cannot any longer keep this country hostage."

That sets up another vote calling for an election in the Commons as early as tomorrow.

Mr Johnson said: "I simply do not believe that this House is capable of delivering on the priorities of the people, whether that means Brexit or anything else."

This breaking news story is being updated.

(Image: Getty Images)

Jeremy Corbyn said Labour would "obviously look and scrutinise" the government's bill before making a decision to see if it met the test of ruling out a no-deal Brexit.

He said: "We look forward to a clear, definitive decision that no deal is absolutely off the table and there is no danger of this Prime Minister not sticking to his word."

It came after party abstained on the vote under the FTPA.

Mr Corbyn also warned that without guarantees that students at university wouldn't be disenfranchised that he would not back any calls for a vote.

It means chances of a snap election before Christmas leapt dramatically after Mr Johnson signalled he would work with the Lib Dems and SNP to secure a poll by other means.

The Prime Minister will tomorrow urge MPs to finally back a poll after his pledge to deliver Brexit “do or die” by October 31st was ripped up by the EU.

His Brexit promise was officially in tatters as EU leaders agreed Parliament’s request for a “flextension” until 31 January 2020.

Mr Johnson faced the humiliation of Brexit being delayed for the third time since 52% of voters voted to quit the EU in June 2016.

But the PM faces a battle with his own Tory MPs as many want him to try to get his Brexit deal over the line before going to the country.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Now the Government will press ahead with a second attempt at getting a festive election.

They will table a short bill which only needs to get half of all voting MPs to back it - although it was unclear whether they would be able to agree on a December 9 or 12 date.

It is a high risk strategy from the PM as the bill could also be amended to include votes for EU citizens or to lower campaign spending limits.

Yet Labour was also in turmoil over a general election with its own MPs planning a mass rebellion if whipped to vote for it.

One shadow cabinet minister told the Mirror: “We recognise that the election is likely to pass in a simple bill vote, but our MPs aren’t in a good place for an election and are refusing to vote.”

(Image: Getty Images)

No10 said it would consider tabling an “almost identical” bill to the one proposed by the Lib Dems and SNP - with sources admitting it would mean dropping Mr Johnson’s own withdrawal bill and the date of the election being explicit in the fresh legislation. Furious Labour MPs have blasted the bid as a “ridiculous stunt”.

But despite Labour’s fury and initial Tory brush-offs the fresh election bid appeared to be gathering momentum.

The Government still has the option of leaving the EU earlier - at the end of November or December - if MPs and the European Parliament pass a withdrawal agreement before then.

The development is damaging for the PM who repeatedly promised he would not ask for a delay to Brexit - claiming he would rather “die in a ditch” than fail to leave on October 31st. Tory MPs are also worried about the threat they face from the Brexit party at a general election
description: MPs rejected the PMs bid to call an election under the Fixed Term Parliament Act, after Labour said the Prime Minister's word couldn't be trusted
